Posts.Content: one2beamup wrote: My surgeon is really in a wad right now. I will skip over the details (and the fact that he called me at home on a Saturday to push his case AGAIN), and cut to the chase. He says I need to have a mast NOW, because I had two tumors and there's a 50% chance I have another one. I don't have a problem doing the mast if it's necessary, but my Radiologist and Oncologist agree that I can do chemo first, and that it won't hurt my recurrence risk. And I can take the time to rationally decide on the surgery aspect (and get the BRCA test). Then after chemo is done, I can get more surgery if necessary (or go right to radiation). He is adamant that the mast should happen first and not the chemo. I know if plenty of women who had chemo first, even know someone who didn't have clear margins, and had her chemo first then a bilat mast. Have you ever heard that chemo shouldn't come first? I trust my other doctors, and will be getting a second opinion, but I'm really curious if his rant has any merit. TIA! :) edited to add: In case it helps, I am stage II with a grade III cancer, two tumors 2cm and 1.2, cm, no lymph nodes but did have lymphovascular invasion, my PET scan was clear, MRI shows a "spot" that may or may not be cancer and will surely have to be investigated at some point, ER+, PR+ and her2/neu+. I'm starting AC 4X next Thursday, then 3 months of T, herceptin and tamoxifen. Dx 12/19/2007, IDC, 2cm, Stage II, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Is My Surgeon Nuts, Or Did You Hear This Too???? one2beamup Panchoandlefty

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2008 10:13AM one2beamup wrote: Hi all, It's been a long time since I've posted. My chemo started on Jan 31, and I'm halfway through. It's been a challenge, but I'm doing ok! I did see another surgeon this week, and he says that mastectomy is not even a conversation we need to have. He's consulting with my other doctors, but doesn't think he will change his mind. I already know that my radiation oncologist (who is the chief of the cancer center at one of our hospitals here) agrees. I had said that I wanted to know how much my recurrence risk percentage would drop if I had my boobs off. He said it doesn't work that way, and that I shouldn't be so willing to sacrifice a part of my body when the payback wouldn't be worth it. He's not concerned about recurrence of breast cancer; he says that I should be more concerned about the risk of another type of cancer. Since BC is so "easily" diagnosed and treatable, I shouldn't just have the surgery "just in case". My oncologist put my risk of another cancer at 15% based on the treatment regimen she is giving me. So I assumed that I could lower that risk by having a mast. But apparently that's not how it works. So, I'm going to consult with the others too of course, and might even get a third opinion, but I'm happy so far. I'd like to avoid that surgery if at all possible!
Posts.Title: Is My Surgeon Nuts, Or Did You Hear This Too???? one2beamup Panchoandlefty

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2008 04:38PM one2beamup wrote: Oh wow, this is great. I'll have to look up what it says about my cancer type. Thanks so much for sharing this!
Posts.Title: Is My Surgeon Nuts, Or Did You Hear This Too???? one2beamup Panchoandlefty

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2008 09:22AM - edited Jan 27, 2008 09:26AM by one2beamup Ann, you described the situation very accurately! I know that no one knows with 100% certainty which way is better. But I know my doctors are up to date on the information out there, and trust they they are as right as can be. Deciding to just trust someone and go with their recommendation takes away a lot of my stress. If the surgeon doesn't lay off, he will be sorry. Don't make my NY come out! Don't make me get my flying monkeys!!! Can someone explain "neoadjuvant" therapy, vs. "adjuvant"? I don't know what the difference is.
Posts.Title: Is My Surgeon Nuts, Or Did You Hear This Too???? one2beamup Panchoandlefty

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2008 02:56PM one2beamup wrote: Thank you again to everyone. I know I'm making the right decision for me, and that feels good! I'll take whatever good feelings I can get right now! Wednesday I'm chopping my hair off, and Thursday the chemo begins. BRING IT ON!!!
Posts.Title: Is My Surgeon Nuts, Or Did You Hear This Too???? one2beamup Panchoandlefty

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2008 06:06AM one2beamup wrote: Thank you everyone! I gave the surgeon a BIG speech when he called, about how I have a TEAM of doctors, and they need to determine together what is best for me. And then I will make the decision on what to do, not THEM. It is my body, and I call the shots, not him or any of the other doctors. I also told him that I never said I wouldn't do the mast, just that I wanted to do chemo first. And that if he had just LISTENED to me the three times I was in his office, he would have KNOWN that. He is the only one who is putting his foot down about doing surgery first. I was SO great in that conversation and totally caught him off guard. I don't think he's used to his patients standing up like that and reminding him that it's OUR bodies, not his. I was doing an end-zone dance after I hung up the phone. It felt so good! Anyway, I had already decided to get a new surgeon, and he of course doesn't know that (because first he needs to put in my port tomorrow!). I'm done with him. He is not a team player and he does not want to accept what the rad and onc are suggesting. I'm going ahead with the chemo, and I'm not worried about that course of action at all. I'm calling another surgeon tomorrow (who the rad had suggested) and making an appointment to see him. I will definitely keep you posted on what happens.
Posts.Title: Is My Surgeon Nuts, Or Did You Hear This Too???? one2beamup Panchoandlefty

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2008 03:08PM - edited Jan 26, 2008 03:15PM by one2beamup The MRI was both breasts, the other one was clear. The tumors were only 2cm apart. Same quadrant. My radiologist (who is the chief of one of the cancer centers here) said that she does not know where he is getting his stats, and that there is no study to support them. The MRI was done after the lumpectomy, but the films didn't show anything really, just the report. So we're not sure right now what it is, but it would be removed later (either lumpectomy or mast). She said that it didn't matter if I did chemo first and then the surgery from a recurrence risk perspective. I will be getting a second opinion from another surgeon, but I'm not sure how quickly I can get the appointment. Also, I'm not sure how much input the surgeon is supposed to have as far as timing? Who really knows for sure which should happen first? One doctor tells me that it doesn't matter if I do chemo first, and the surgeon says it does matter, that this is "news to him" that chemo can go first.
Posts.Title: Is My Surgeon Nuts, Or Did You Hear This Too???? one2beamup Panchoandlefty

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2008 04:24PM one2beamup wrote: The link didn't work. I'd really like to see the article. I agree that it's time for a new surgeon. I'm going to make some calls on Monday. :)

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2008 11:43PM one2beamup wrote: Thanks everyone for your support! It actually feels like it's easing a bit. I start AC on Thursday for 3 months, then 3 months of Taxol. I'm getting my long hair chopped off tomorrow night. :)

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2008 05:19PM one2beamup wrote: I forgot to mention that he left an iv needle and shunt in there, because that way they won't have to stick me again for my first treatment while I'm still sore. He thought my treatment was today, but it's Thursday. So maybe some of the pain is from the needle.
Posts.Title: OOOWWWWWWW!!!! one2beamup thedudess

Posts.Content: one2beamup wrote: I had my port put in yesterday, and I am in SO MUCH pain! My lumpectomy was nothing compared to this. It's sharp pain, and I'm sore all over the place. They did have to move it (because the xray after the first placement showed they had to) so there was "extra" activity in there. But I had no idea it was going to hurt so much! Just standing up causes sharp pains. Am I alone? And how long is it going to take for this to ease? Sorry, I'm cranky (after hardly sleeping last night) and had to bitch! Dx 12/19/2007, IDC, 2cm, Stage II, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
